articles.headline: War Veterans’ Concussions Are Often Overlooked
articles.snippet: The complications from concussions, a signature injury of the Iraq war, often are not recognized in singular ways.
articles.abstract: The complications from concussions, a signature injury of the Iraq war, often are not recognized in singular ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Staff Sgt. Kevin Owsley is not quite sure what rattled his brain in 2004: the roadside bomb that exploded about a yard from his Humvee or the rocket-propelled grenade that flung him across a road as he walked to a Porta Potti on base six weeks later.

articles.headline: Gulf Countries Remain Tied to the Dollar
articles.snippet: With the dollar’s modest comeback and oil’s retreat, policy makers in the region have been bolstered in their resolve to keep currency pegs in place.
articles.abstract: With the dollar’s modest comeback and oil’s retreat, policy makers in the region have been bolstered in their resolve to keep currency pegs in place.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  As oil prices soared and the dollar’s value plunged, a chorus of academics and policy experts took up the cry that Saudi Arabia and neighboring Persian Gulf countries should abandon their currency pegs to a depreciating dollar to help combat the social ravages of inflation that were spreading across the region.

articles.headline: Enclave Hails Tight Embrace From Moscow
articles.snippet: Russia’s Parliament wants independence for South Ossetia and Abkhazia, but most Western countries support Georgia’s territorial integrity.
articles.abstract: Russia’s Parliament wants independence for South Ossetia and Abkhazia, but most Western countries support Georgia’s territorial integrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: TSKHINVALI, Georgia  The last time South Ossetia declared independence from Georgia  the last three times, actually  hardly anyone noticed. Even Russia, its great friend to the north, declined to take up the cause.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Matt Siegel

articles.headline: Communities Become Home Buyers to Fight Decay
articles.snippet: Several big cities are using tax dollars and private funds to buy and refurbish foreclosed properties to help declining neighborhoods survive.
articles.abstract: Several big cities are using tax dollars and private funds to buy and refurbish foreclosed properties to help declining neighborhoods survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As a wave of home foreclosures courses through the United States, some of the nation’s hardest hit cities think they have found a way to ease the blight left on their communities by the crisis.

articles.headline: Democrats Take Stage, and the G.O.P. Crowds On
articles.snippet: A team of Republican operatives dispatched to crash the Democrats’ party was reveling in its accomplishments.
articles.abstract: A team of Republican operatives dispatched to crash the Democrats’ party was reveling in its accomplishments.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER  In a modern production studio about a mile from where the Democrats were opening their convention here Monday, a SWAT team of Republican operatives dispatched to crash Senator Barack Obama’s party was reveling in its accomplishments.

articles.headline: Honda Stays True to Efficient Driving
articles.snippet: In today’s fuel-conscious automotive market, Honda is reaping the rewards for its commitment to building fuel-efficient, environmentally friendly cars.
articles.abstract: In today’s fuel-conscious automotive market, Honda is reaping the rewards for its commitment to building fuel-efficient, environmentally friendly cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORRANCE, Calif. — During the glory days of big pickups and sport utility vehicles, one automaker steadfastly refused to join the party.

articles.headline: Summer Story Lines Have Legs
articles.snippet: With Wall Street virtually empty, it is worth trying to peer around the corner to see what will happen when everyone gets back to business after Labor Day.
articles.abstract: With Wall Street virtually empty, it is worth trying to peer around the corner to see what will happen when everyone gets back to business after Labor Day.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year again, the last week of summer on Wall Street. Getting a table at San Pietro is easy; a tee time at Maidstone Club in East Hampton, less so. With the Street virtually empty, except for all those Lehman Brothers executives working the phones in search of a buyer, it’s worth reflecting on the crisis gripping the financial world and trying to peer around the corner to see what will happen when everyone gets back to business after Labor Day.

articles.headline: Appeals Evoking American Dream Rally Democrats
articles.snippet: The Democrats sought to present an emotionally powerful two-act evening, featuring Senator Edward M. Kennedy, struggling with brain cancer, and Michelle Obama.
articles.abstract: The Democrats sought to present an emotionally powerful two-act evening, featuring Senator Edward M. Kennedy, struggling with brain cancer, and Michelle Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Senator Edward M. Kennedy, struggling with brain cancer, arrived on Monday night at the Democratic National Convention in a triumphant appearance that evoked 50 years of party history as Democrats gathered to nominate Senator Barack Obama for president.

articles.headline: Russia Backs Independence of Georgian Enclaves
articles.snippet: Russia formally recognized the independence of South Ossetia and Abkhazia in a challenge to the West.
articles.abstract: Russia formally recognized the independence of South Ossetia and Abkhazia in a challenge to the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Russia on Tuesday recognized the independence of two enclaves that have long sought to secede from neighboring Georgia. The action deepened strains with the West over the conflict in the economically vital crossroads of the Caucasus and roiled a broader debate over how to respond to separatist movements around the world.

articles.headline: Home Prices Still Falling, but the Pace Is Slowing
articles.snippet: Prices fell again in June, but a separate report showed that more Americans bought new homes in July.
articles.abstract: Prices fell again in June, but a separate report showed that more Americans bought new homes in July.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home sales have begun to stabilize as sharply reduced prices lured buyers back into the market in July, according to a pair of reports issued this week. And prices, once plummeting at a breakneck pace, fell in June at a more moderate clip.
